description: Indicates the current state of this cluster disk.
interpretation: Values: Online (100), Online pending (90), Inherited (80), Initializing (70), Pending (60), Offline pending (50), Unknown (40), Offline (20), Failed (0). A failed disk adversely impacts availability. Use detailed diagnosis to see the owner node, path, and group.
troubleshootingSteps: Check the physical disk connectivity and SAN/storage array status; verify if the LUN is presented correctly to all cluster nodes.[web:431][web:437][web:440]
If the disk is 'Failed' or stuck in 'Online Pending', run cluster validation tests for storage to identify SCSI reservation conflicts or driver issues.[web:419][web:431][web:434]
Inspect the System and FailoverClustering event logs (Event IDs 1069, 1034, 1066) for specific error codes like 'Disk is reserved by another node' or 'Access Denied'.[web:419][web:429][web:431]
Clear any 'stuck' reservations using `Clear-ClusterDiskReservation` (forcefully) if a node retains a lock on the disk after a crash, but use caution to avoid data corruption.[web:429][web:431]
If the disk is marked Read-Only, use Diskpart or PowerShell to clear the Read-Only attribute, which can happen after certain failure scenarios.[web:437][web:440]

description: Indicates the total capacity of this cluster disk.
troubleshootingSteps: Verify that the reported capacity matches the LUN size on the storage array; discrepancies might indicate partition alignment issues or unallocated space that can be expanded.[web:438][web:439]

description: Indicates the space in this cluster disk that is in use currently.
interpretation: Ideally, the value should be low. A high value indicates excessive space usage.
troubleshootingSteps: Identify large files or folders (e.g., VHDX files, ISOs, logs) consuming space using tools like TreeSize or PowerShell scripts adapted for Cluster Shared Volumes (CSV).[web:433][web:439]
Check for shadow copies or system volume information bloat that might be consuming hidden space.[web:438][web:439]

description: Indicates the amount of space in this cluster disk that is currently unused.
interpretation: A high value is desired for this measure.
troubleshootingSteps: Monitor free space trends to predict when capacity will be exhausted; proactive expansion is better than reacting to a full disk.[web:433][web:436][web:439]

If free space is critically low, immediately free up space by deleting non-essential files or migrating workloads to other volumes to prevent service stoppages (e.g., paused VMs).[web:433][web:435][web:441]

measurement: Percentage of cluster disk space used
description: Indicates the percentage of the total capacity of this cluster disk that is utilized.
interpretation: A value close to 100% indicates abnormal usage. Compare across disks to balance loads. Check this before assigning new services.
troubleshootingSteps: Set alerts for high usage thresholds (e.g., Warning at 80%, Critical at 90%) to allow time for remediation.[web:433][web:435][web:436]
Balance storage loads by moving virtual machines or data to less utilized cluster disks or CSVs using Live Migration.[web:433][web:435][web:441]
Expand the LUN on the SAN and then extend the volume in Windows Disk Management if usage is legitimately high and cannot be reduced.[web:433][web:435][web:441]
